segments.text: This is an interview with Jerry Singleton by Barbara Bell on May 4, 1989, in Dallas, Texas, concerning his involvement in the Vietnam War.
Due to the continuing interest in the Vietnam War by historians, students, and researchers, I would like to submit this tape to the Texas A&M archives.
Is that OK with you?
Yes, it is.
OK, thanks.
OK, I wanted to begin with asking you about your military career before the American involvement in Vietnam.
Isn't it true that you had started out choosing the military as a career?
You didn't just enlist at the time of the war?
Not exactly Barbara.
I went to the Air Force Academy.
That was the source of my commission.
My plan when I went there was to fulfill my obligation which was going to be a total of about five years including pilot training.
and I planned after that to get out and go do some other things.
Okay.
As I got into the Air Force on active duty, the conviction to get out at the end of my obligation became less strong, although it was still at least off and on part of the plan.
Of course, I was shot down
before I got to the termination of my obligation.
So it was kind of academic after that point because I already had more than 10 years in when I got back home.
OK. What was your rank at the time of your involvement in the war?
What year did you actually enter the war in?
I went to Southeast Asia in August, or excuse me, October of 1965.
And I was first lieutenant then, a pilot.
OK.
And then, because you just relate your experiences, how much involved in the war before you got shot down?
How many months?
One.
One month.
I was over there a very short time.
I was in an air rescue squadron.
Our mission was to rescue other American military pilots that were shot down over enemy territory, especially over the north.
We were the first what we call permanent party contingent with a long range rescue capability to be over there.
Everybody else that had been there before us doing that kind of mission had been there on a temporary duty assignment, usually not to last more than a month or two.
We were called in over there because that was just about the time the air war in North Vietnam was really getting to be substantial and regular.
Earlier than fall of 65, there had been some airstrikes, but they had been sporadic.
There had been no continuous strikes.
OK. What was your own personal attitude towards the American involvement at the time that you were sent over?
I personally felt like it was a war that needed to be fought.
That there were, there was, well, first of all, North Vietnam had been partitioned in 1954.
At the end of the French involvement in Indochina.
At that point, North and South Vietnam were, the country was divided into North and South.
North was communist, the South was not.
at least as far as I'm able to tell generally, that was by the choice of each country.
The North Vietnamese, like communism typically, cannot tolerate a contradiction.
And they won't settle for, not only will they not settle for any alternative in their own domain, but they feel,
really an evangelistic obligation to reform the rest of the world, they see it as reformation to make the rest of the world communist.
And everything that I have seen about communism, at least through about five years ago, put them in a position of
of allowing themselves only one of three alternatives with regard to the world, the non-communist world.
And that was either to convert us or kill us or die in the effort.
Generally, the South Vietnamese did not want to be communist.
That doesn't mean that they did everything right either.
They're human beings like all of us.
But they chose to pursue their own goals with a non-communist governmental organization.
The North Vietnamese would not stand for that if they felt there was anything they could do about it.
And the question really was not could they do anything about it, but what.
And they chose

a a form of promoting their ideal that was I guess generally attributed to Mao Zedong the protracted conflict which amounts to continuing to apply whatever means are appropriate at the time whether it's political military or somewhere in between
to convert whoever it is that's their target at the time.
Of course, in this case, it was more than just South Vietnam.
Their target was Laos, South Vietnam, Cambodia, and a longer time range target, of course, also was Thailand.
They were active in all four of those countries.
Their primary effort was in South Vietnam, and that's where our confrontation came.

I felt like we ought to be there, not because I necessarily agreed with everything that the South Vietnamese were doing, but I felt that they ought to have the right to decide for themselves without somebody holding a gun to their head trying to convince them to choose another path.
And that's what I felt like North Vietnam was doing.
I've heard the argument before that we were imposing our government upon the South Vietnamese.
How do you react to that?
I think perhaps we were doing more of that than we should.
I'm not sure that we had a whole lot of choice given the situation.
In other words, we don't want to take our Army, Navy, and Air Force
and give them to a commander of another country and say, OK, we're going to let you use our soldiers to fight your war.
That means that we're going to have to have some say in the way the war is prosecuted by our side, our side meaning us as well as the South Vietnamese and others that would ally with us.
in Southeast Asia.
So your overall attitude as you went over was, would you say enthusiastic or at least supportive?
Supportive of the goal.
I think there's a popular misconception among civilians about military people, those who willingly and voluntarily choose a military career, that we're hawks.
That's perhaps true of a very, very minor minority.
But of the group in general, just the opposite is true.
Because when war comes, we're the ones that pay the price first, we're the ones that pay the price most, and our families too.
That's the last thing in the world we want.
My personal feeling was that I felt privileged to live in the kind of country that we lived in.
more freedom than any place else in the world that I knew about.
Freedom to just live our lives the way we saw fit, make our own choices, pursue personal goals.
We didn't have that freedom except by having earned it, mostly in armed combat.
To earn it initially as well as to preserve it from those that wanted to oppose some of their ideals on us.

I also felt that I could not expect to or demand the right to continue enjoying that kind of freedom and all the benefits of living here and ask someone else to go out and do the fighting for me to continue to protect it and preserve it for us as well as other
nations in the world that want to have the same right of choice that we do.
I didn't feel like I had the right to expect someone else to do all the dirty work and consequently while I certainly didn't want to go to war I wasn't dragging my heels.
It seemed like an appropriate obligation and I would certainly

Especially at that time, given the nature of communism as we were able to know it as it manifested itself, I would much rather knock heads with them someplace else than having to do it in my own backyard when my wife and kids are sitting in the house.
Would you say then, or did you feel that the North Vietnamese attack upon South Vietnam was maybe an indirect attack?
upon America?
You were talking about defending your country, so did you feel that if it went too far it could eventually threaten us or threaten our allies?
Well, the activity in Southeast Asia specifically was not a threat to us.
As one more manifestation of the Communist desire to
convert the world, or they would feel it was an obligation.
It was a part of the same effort.
That particular part was not pointed directly at me and my family in this country.
But if they hadn't had to exert time and effort in prosecuting that war over there,
it would have left them a lot more resources to employ in a manner that would have had a more direct effect on our country.
OK. Another one of the issues brought up at times is that some of the people that went to war had the black and white mentality of previous wars.
The World War II, we're good, they're bad.
the same with Korea, and that maybe that wasn't necessarily applicable to the Vietnam War.
Do you feel that that attitude was prevalent, that yes, we're good, they're bad, and that's the way it is, we need to go out and defeat them?
Or do you think it was a little more gray maybe once we got into it?
I think it depends on who you're asking the question to.
For me, the lines were pretty clearly drawn.

And I say that not because it seemed so white on our side, but because the communists had made it clear that they would not accept anything less or anything else than a communist-dominated, ruled, operated world.
they gave every indication that since the end of the Second World War that that was their goal.
Every time we turned around they were taking off another chunk here and another bite there and I really felt like like the communist world primarily dominated by

Soviet communism and Chinese communism there is a difference but their goals were the same that if if we did not stand up every time they confronted part of the non-communist world someplace there wasn't anyone else who really had the
the strength to do it.
And if we didn't stand up, and every time we did, they took another piece out of what had formerly been a non-communist part of the work.
It was chipping away?
Yes.
And everything they said and everything they did indicated they had a single mindset, and it was all going that same direction.
So in that sense, it was black and white.
In another sense, there was a whole lot of gray even to me.
Our nation's not perfect.
And as much as I dislike communism in general, everything they're trying to do is not bad.
So it's a mix.
And I think for our nation, I think
whatever issues people may have thought of regarding that war, in general, were extremely clouded at best.
This is a question that historian after historian after historian has analyzed.
And as succinctly as you can, what is your opinion on the reason why we lost the war?
Do you feel it's the way we fought it, the government, the administration?
lack of leadership qualities.
There's been so many different theories.
Before we get into your own personal experiences, just as an overall view.
I don't think we ever decided what we intended to do when we went there.
That's about as succinct as it can be.
We never had well-defined goals or objectives.
And it ate our lunch the whole time we were involved.

it hampered our leadership because without a goal they felt like they ought to do something but they didn't know what and every action was taken they had no goal to measure it by to say yes we're going the right direction or no we need to do something else and kind of feeling their way along yeah now that's very simplified there's a whole lot more to it than that and i think
probably just about any of the theories that have been espoused in this regard at least have some merit and have a part to play someplace.
Okay.
Well, let's move along then to your own personal experience since that's the most interesting to me at this point.
Again, if you want to start with the actual date of your capture, however you want to go about it, you were flying, were you a pilot at the time?
I was a pilot.
We were on a rescue mission.
We were attempting to rescue an F-105 pilot that had been shot down a day earlier.
There was a search mission in progress trying to locate him.
One of the search aircraft was shot down, and we were scrambled to rescue the pilot of one of the search aircraft.
That was the 6th of November, 1965.
We were shot down that afternoon on the way in to make the rescue.
About what part, what area was going around?
We were about 35 to 40 miles from Hanoi, which was, we were flying a rescue helicopter unarmed.
It was a very early version.
very limited capability and increased vulnerability for a number of reasons, which really put us between a rock and a hard place.
It was also early in the war.
We had no rescue history to learn from, at least in the Vietnamese context.
So we were trying to figure out how to write the book as we were flying our missions.
And you were first taken to, apparently you were shifted from several different camps, correct?
Where did they take you first?
Well, I managed to play hide and seek for about five days before they finally caught me.
And was taken out to a road.
I was just guarded kind of in an open cave, a half-open cave, for a couple of days.
They took me to a couple of the local villages, and I was the show-and-tell for the local political cadres.
I was taken to another prison that I'm sure had been used by the French, was now used by the North Vietnamese for their own political prisoners, I'm sure.
I spent about five days there, and then was taken to Hanoi.
That was, in Hanoi, was kind of the introduction to the real POW system in North Vietnam.

Up until then, we were just being escalated up the chain from the people who captured us and really didn't know what to do into people who were a little better trained, a little closer to the home operation until we finally arrived in Hanoi.
What are your first impressions of the place?
Were you blindfolded a lot of the time or did you see it as you were walking in?
We were blindfolded.
There were three of us, I think, being moved at the same time, three members of my crew.
We had not gotten together on the ground.
We hadn't seen each other since bailout.
We did get to identify each other with names, but we'd catch a rifle button aside for talking and looking out from under the blindfold.
So we were doing as much as we could get away with.
My first sensation was being hungry, because I'd been five days without food or water.
I felt like that was the way I started off, and I really never got full until I got out.
I believe it.
It wasn't quite that bad, because toward the end, they did try to fatten us up to make things look better.

That, the time when I was captured was still early enough in the war when they had not even formulated a, the North Vietnamese had not even formulated a procedure as to what to do with us, much less a plan.
So it was a lot easier for us to get away with things
We had been through survival training, we had been through simulated POW situations, and at least had some idea of what to expect.
I was surprised at how good the training was.
Was it fairly accurate?
I had no surprises for the first year.
Wow.
And I could write the script for them when they took me to that first village that I just described.
One of the local political cadres was supposed to be interrogating me and speaking through an interpreter.
He wouldn't answer his questions.
So I knew that wasn't going to last long.
The next thing he pulled out his little 9mm automatic and put it up to my head and I was going to have to answer the questions or he was going to shoot me.
Essentially, from the survival training, I knew one of two things were going to happen.
Either he was going to kill me or he wasn't.
And whether I answered his silly questions wasn't going to make any difference.
So that's kind of the way things went, at least through that first year.
Once we got into Hanoi and into the hands of those who were prepared to guard us and treat us as prisoners, things got to be a little different.
Some of the senior officers had already been very severely tortured, badly mistreated, and we were the whole time.
I say the whole time until the end.
Right before the end, things changed rather substantially.
But the
All of the communist countries that signed the Geneva Conventions on the treatment of prisoners of war took exception to one of the provisions.
And with invariably American military men captured by communists are treated as war criminals.
And they claim that's what we are because of the exception they take.
So that was their attitude toward us.
Also,
The general communist approach to our treatment of prisoners of war is exploitation.
They're the ones who first really used that idea.
Historically, before that point, you might try to torture the prisoners to get some military information.
Generally, other countries didn't want to keep prisoners because it just meant you had to house and feed them, and they were excess baggage.
But either extraction of military information or treating them as excess baggage was the only approach toward prisoners.
The communists decided to exploit them for political purposes.
And what that meant, among other things, was they were continually trying to extract or extort some kind of information
paper or statement from us that they could use for political propaganda.

And they would call you in and want you to sign a statement of discrediting your country and then... Yeah, except usually they wanted us to write it because they weren't that sophisticated in English to do it themselves.
And that left us a little bit out too.
On the topic of exploitation, one good example of that would be the March of Hanoi, and you took part in this, correct?
Yes.
Can you talk about that?
Apparently there were different versions of what it was for, depending on who you heard, which government talked about it.
Okay.
It was really bad news all the way, Barbara.
It appeared from everything that I've seen and heard that they had probably three purposes in mind.
The most important was pumping up their own people.
North Vietnam had been bombed rather heavily for a year by that time.
They had taken a lot of hits up there.
They needed something to pump their own people up and say, hey, come on, take some more of this.
It's going to be worth it.
We were the only thing that they had to show for their efforts.
Supposedly, they were accomplishing a lot in South Vietnam, but it wasn't anything that people could look at.
But they could look at us, and we were their victories.
So they took probably what amounted to about half the prisoners.
I never bothered to try to quantify it, but about half what they had at that time.
They handcuffed us in pairs, separated each pair.
We were just walking in files, one pair behind the next, separated each pair by probably, oh, initially eight or 10 yards.
When the parade first started off, the sidewalk was really crowded, but the people there didn't know what to do.
It was just kind of this very awkward, kind of an incomprehensible, well, yeah, I see, but what do I do?
Silence.
So we were unblindfolded at this time.
There was a North Vietnamese guard on each side of a pair, one of our prison guards.
They had their rifles with them.
Then it was very easy to pick out who were the instigators, the local political leaders.
And they'd start some kind of yell.
It was like a cheer.
And they'd turn around and the people behind them, yeah, yeah, me too, me too.
And you could see this whole thing then get started that way.
And it was slow getting started.
But once it got started, it really boiled over.
And it's a long story in and of itself.
But by the time we finished, I really didn't think we were going to get out alive.
I really didn't.
They were throwing rocks, bricks, whatever they could.
They were trying to mob us.
And before the parade ended, the guards that were there to make sure we stayed in our place as prisoners were literally using their rifles to protect us in the crowd.
Rifle butts, the barrel of the rifle, whatever they could.
They didn't shoot anybody that I saw.
But the guards and the officers were doing the same thing.
It was very apparent.
that the whole thing got completely out of hand, and they weren't ready to handle it.
And a lot of our guys took a lot of bumps and bruises, but that was all the physical damage that we suffered from it.
I don't know how long it lasted.
It seemed like it was a couple of weeks.
It was probably about an hour and a half, two hours at the most.
And that kind of thing never happened again as a result.
They threatened it a number of times, at least within the prison system.
Interrogators threatened us, but it never happened again.
And how did North Vietnamese interpret this to the world, their version of it?
It was just their proof of ongoing victory.
See just a sampling of the many hundreds of American flyers that we've captured.
which is the result of the many thousands of airplanes we shot down.
And I forget to, we figured out a pretty accurate ratio of the number of planes they actually shot down to what they claimed.
I forget right now what it was, but it was somewhere between six and ten to one planes per actuals.
Slightly exaggerated.
Yes, oh yeah.
Okay, well,
Within the camp itself, you talked about you were kept in various size compartments, from solitary to 50.
Can you discuss a few of those?
Perhaps the solitary, that was at the beginning of your term, correct?
Yeah.
First of all, most of the places that we stayed,

uh several of the places where prisoners were kept were not designed as prisons to begin one of the biggest apparently had been a french film studio and i spent several months there several years there as it accumulated over the time that's where i spent about the first six months in solitary confinement i was
two weeks in the Hanoi Hilton in the section we called Heartbreak Hotel.
Then was taken to, we called it Camp A at that time.
And spent the better part of the next six months there.
My cell was, for the most part, was a large room with windows that had bars in it.
and shutters on the outside of the windows so I couldn't look out.
The bed was a bunch of boards nailed together and sat directly on the floor.
I was given some string to tie a mosquito net up over there, tie the string to the bars on the windows and at least give me a place to stay out on mosquitoes at night.
I had a room probably initially as big as this room.
Which is about?
Oh, what, 16 feet square, something like that, roughly.
So it wasn't the small cell that I would imagine.
Not initially.
But this was just because they were looking for places to keep us.
They weren't prepared to handle prisoners of war.
They hadn't planned for that logistically.
So initially that was a big room.
I had it all to myself.
The only furniture was a bed and a tin bucket over in the corner that had a wooden lid that sat on the top that was my toilet.
How did you, did you make use of this area then for what physical exercise?
Did you, I was going to talk about the different ways you basically exercise both mentally and physically.
Yes.
You can take them in either order you want.
I'm assuming that you started to communicate with people
next to you or did you wait until you got back to the Hanoi Hilton?
Okay, the primary communication tool was what we came to call a tap code.
Are you familiar with what that is?
Right.
Okay, you know how that works then.
The North Vietnamese really helped us out a lot in passing that tap code around.
When I was still at Heartbreak Hotel, I was taken to another room for interrogation.
was left there to kind of cool my heels and apparently make me nervous for a while.
Sat in front of this desk on a stool.
The desk was for the officer who was going to come interrogate me.
And there wasn't anybody there, so I started looking around.
And right square in the middle on the top of this desk, carved with a nail, was the matrix for the tap code.
And a little note above it says, all American POWs learned this.
And they didn't read English very well, I'm assuming.
And, you know, some guy that had been there before me and had had time took his nail, and that was one of the primary tools we had, used it for almost everything.
Eventually they figured that out, right?
Yeah.
And put it into at least the passing it around that way.
Yes.
But it got around.
Everybody learned it.
Let's see, I've lost track of what the question was.
Well, I was going to say, how long did it take you to learn it?
I mean, the first six months you were there, did someone initiate it next door to you?
Well, I mentioned Jim Stopdale.
Okay.
And I had been in heartbreak about five minutes when he started talking to me.
And, you know,
filled me in very quickly on communication procedures.
There were guys on the cells on either side.
There were a total of six or seven in the heartbreak cell block at that time.
We were able to communicate by talking fairly well in that situation.
So I didn't have to use the tap code a lot until I got to another camp a couple weeks later.
Was it very thin walls or through the window more?
Most of the time, the walls were pretty thick.
They would often leave a dead space, even in the walls between rooms, for insulation, especially in the prisons.
I'm sure they did it to limit communications.
But we finally reached the point, especially in the larger cells, where we had
some other capabilities that we didn't when we were alone, one or two guys, of being able to talk through those walls verbally.
You had to make sure you were secure as far as the North Vietnamese were concerned.
But everybody came online very quickly.
And as far as the ability and learning the skills we had there to communicate were concerned.
That was one of our primary efforts.
teaching new guys how to communicate and establishing initial communications with them was one of the things that everybody pulled out all the stops on.
A lot of guys got caught communicating and knew that they were going to be tortured for it, knowing full well it was going to happen.
But they went ahead and did it to establish initial communications with the new guys.
And that kind of, just talking about that, I guess,
signify the incredible importance of the communication.
Yes.
I was going to say, to retain your sanity in that entire situation, would you say that that would be one of the major, major aspects that got you through the whole thing?
It was absolutely essential.

It was very easy to tell when a guy had been even with a large group for a long time and taken out for just a week or two and held in solitary confinement while they were trying to lean on him for a war crimes confession or something like that.
People alone tend to get out of balance, at least as far as society is concerned.
We need each other to say, hey, you're great on most things, but that idea's crazy.
Here's why.
If you don't have somebody there to tell you that, it's very easy to avoid realizing that one idea out of 10 really is crazy.
So we knew it was essential.
We'd been trained beforehand in the survival schools that we'd gone through to communicate.
Had they taught you any codes at all in the survival?
That was an old Boy Scout code that some guy had brought in and said, hey, it'll work here.
The Morse code didn't work as well there.
This worked a lot better.
It was a lot simpler.
for what we had to work with.
What kind of things besides names?
I read that people memorize all the names of who was in their cell.
What kind of things did you talk about?
Was it mainly who is where and what's going on?
Or was it, what kind of things would you talk about day to day?
OK, the first priority was keeping track of prisoners.
Who's been shot down that hasn't showed up yet that we need to be looking for?
Who do we know that is alive that has been captured in custody of the North Vietnamese?
Where are they?
If they've been moved, where have they been moved to?
If somebody's disappeared, then we gotta figure out what happened to them.
That was the first priority.
The second priority was a combination of finding out what the Vietnamese were currently about
Usually the way they worked would be a single purpose purge.
They'd go through the whole camp.
This week it's going to be war crimes confessions.
Next week it's going to be apologies to the camp commander for communicating.
It can be anything.
Sometimes it was military information.
We wanted to find out what the current purge was about.
Frequently that was the situation and just knowing what they were going to be looking for helped us get better prepared.
I was going to say prepare yourself mentally.
Yeah.
It was a combination of figuring out what the North Vietnamese were about and getting direction from the senior officers.
So the military chain of command, was it somewhat intact?
It was absolutely intact.
Incredibly, wow.
How did that, were there actual orders going?
Okay, the second thing you found out about a guy once you got his name and identified him was his rank and date of rank to know where he fitted into the chain of command.
And you might have one boss one day and a new guy gets shot down and you got a new boss the next day.
they were smart enough to say, okay, who's been running this thing?
What are the policies that the Americans have had up at this point and why?
And I'll get on board from there and make changes slowly.
How did everybody react to that?
Was there ever an incident of, I really don't care what he says, I'm just going to do my own thing?
Or was there an overall bond, a unity of, hey, if we don't stick together, we're not going to make it kind of thing?
I would say there were some

When you leave people in that kind of situation where you have aggravations coming from every side for long enough, you're going to get some anger, some disappointment, some disagreement, and it'll be vocalized.
But my experience for the whole seven years there was there was never any doubt about what our responsibility was.
If we were senior, we were to take command.
If we were not senior, we were to fill our place in the chain of command, whatever that might be.
So it worked probably better there than it does here.
It was more important there that we follow that chain of command for a number of reasons.
And we did.
The kind of...
Maybe the type of activities you underwent maybe in the cell by yourself.
I've heard stories about mental type of activities.
Someone who would imagine that he was building a house.
And it would go nail by nail by nail.
Or somebody else would do math problems over and over and over and just work their mind that way.
What kind of things did you do to keep your mind busy?
Well, first of all, physical exercise was important.
And we did that.
to a man, as far as I know.
The amount of that that we could do depended on the diet.
When we were getting bread, we could do better.
When we were getting rice, we couldn't do as well.
And it was very obvious in that kind of a situation.
But almost everybody had some kind of a personal plan of physical exercise.
And it was just about a daily routine.
For the mental activities, there was a lot more variation there.
It depended on the situation.
If you were alone, you had to play solitaire, whatever form that might take.

If you were in a large group like we were toward the end and had more open communications, we had formal classes in science, humanities, foreign languages, math, just about anything you could think of.

A friend of mine who was one of the few pilots shot down who did not have a degree came home after the war, went to get his degree, and was able to validate almost 25 credits, semester hours credit, just because of the
quote courses, unquote, that he took in North Vietnam.
Such as?
What kind of courses were the standard?
Language, math, science.
Those were probably the most useful.
We had one guy in a cell that I was in toward the end there who had been a thermodynamics instructor at the Air Force Academy.
So we had a lot of capability there.
I taught some classes on
French, chemistry, a little bit of math, and bridge.
Now how did the guards react to this?
Because you said at the beginning they were a little, they weren't, you know, they didn't really encourage the communication at all, but then towards the, this was what, in the early 70s?
Yeah, 70, late 71 and thereafter.
Mm-hmm.
late 70 and thereafter.
And at that point they didn't really mind?
They did mind, but they were in a bind then.
Let's see.
It's been a long time, Barbara, since I've done any thinking about this, so I'm a little off on, I'm a little fuzzy on my timing, but several things happened toward the end of the 60s.
Two were extremely important.
One was the families of those who were prisoners or were missing finally got together and began communicating with each other.
Up to that point,
the U.S. government had made a very concerted effort to keep them isolated from each other.
It was a dumb policy.
President Nixon changed that.
And the families got together and organized their own efforts, saying, hey, the government has been able to do absolutely nothing, including they haven't been able to stop the torture.
Is this where the letter-writing campaign began?
Among other things.
Writing letters, bracelets, Bonnie
can tell you volumes about that because she was right in the middle of getting it organized and carrying it out.
But all of a sudden the North Vietnamese realized that they were making Americans as a nation mad at them because of the way they were treating us.
Up to that point
America as a nation had been divided on everything that pertained to the war.
